title: Tweetdeck (twitter owned app) not revoked

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information: I've noticed an issue in tweetdeck & twitter. If you try to revoke tweet deck, no matter what you do, if anyone else is logged in on your account through tweetdeck, they will still be able to use your account. This doesn't properly revoke users, so therefore I thought this as is a bug/problem e.g. if someone gets hacked, but the hacker has added their account to tweetdeck, their account can still be controlled. I am reporting this to twitter because tweetdeck is their app. Please fix this issue.
vulnerability_information_html: I've noticed an issue in tweetdeck & twitter. If you try to revoke tweet deck, no matter what you do, if anyone else is logged in on your account through tweetdeck, they will still be able to use your account. This doesn't properly revoke users, so therefore I thought this as is a bug/problem e.g. if someone gets hacked, but the hacker has added their account to tweetdeck, their account can still be controlled. I am reporting this to twitter because tweetdeck is their app. Please fix this issue.

activities.message: This isn't such a big issue if you haven't been hacked, but take a celebrity for example, their account could be hacked & then added to a deck.
activities.markdown_message: This isn't such a big issue if you haven't been hacked, but take a celebrity for example, their account could be hacked & then added to a deck.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. 

We're unable reproduce your proof of concept. In our tests, the user was logged out of the Tweetdeck account shortly after access was revoked from the Twitter account. Please clarify how you were able to tweet from Tweetdeck after access was revoked. 

Note: Revoking access may take a few minutes, please verify that you've given Twitter.com enough time to revoke access to that application before attempting to tweet from Tweetdeck.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

We're unable reproduce your proof of concept. In our tests, the user was logged out of the Tweetdeck account shortly after access was revoked from the Twitter account. Please clarify how you were able to tweet from Tweetdeck after access was revoked.

Note: Revoking access may take a few minutes, please verify that you've given Twitter.com enough time to revoke access to that application before attempting to tweet from Tweetdeck.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message: I guess this is quite hard to clarify then. I gave an account to my friend, his username is ███ on Twitter. He revoked all the apps. A week later today I am still able to tweet on that account.
activities.markdown_message: I guess this is quite hard to clarify then. I gave an account to my friend, his username is ███ on Twitter. He revoked all the apps. A week later today I am still able to tweet on that account.

activities.message: I also don't know how to show proof it was logged out. I simply have to ability to tweet on accounts regardless of whether I revoke their access.
activities.markdown_message: I also don't know how to show proof it was logged out. I simply have to ability to tweet on accounts regardless of whether I revoke their access.

activities.message:
Hmm, in my tests, I am logged out almost immediately with the error message: 

"TweetDeck no longer has permission to access your main login account @[my account].  You will be logged out in 5 seconds to prevent unauthorized access."

Can you demonstrate this effect using two test accounts in different browsers (like Chrome and Firefox, not two tabs in the same browser) on your own machine? 

Thanks for thinking of Twitter security!
activities.markdown_message:
Hmm, in my tests, I am logged out almost immediately with the error message:

"TweetDeck no longer has permission to access your main login account @[my account]. You will be logged out in 5 seconds to prevent unauthorized access."

Can you demonstrate this effect using two test accounts in different browsers (like Chrome and Firefox, not two tabs in the same browser) on your own machine?

Thanks for thinking of Twitter security!

activities.message: I don't know how it happened, I just can hold accounts on my tweetdeck account. I currently lost access to the Twitter account I was having this bug on though.
activities.markdown_message: I don't know how it happened, I just can hold accounts on my tweetdeck account. I currently lost access to the Twitter account I was having this bug on though.

activities.message:
Since, we're unable to reproduce the issue, I'm afraid that this report doesn't qualify for a reward under this bug bounty program. If you're able provide a working PoC, we'll reevaluate this issue but until then we'll be closing this report. 

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Since, we're unable to reproduce the issue, I'm afraid that this report doesn't qualify for a reward under this bug bounty program. If you're able provide a working PoC, we'll reevaluate this issue but until then we'll be closing this report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message: I have added a new video showing the error, even when I have revoked tweetdeck from the twitter account, and then logged out of tweetdeck and logged back in again tweetdeck is still not revoked. I have had my friend try to revoke his account also, and it did not revoke it either. He was using a different computer, different account  too. I think I have found the problem, if it is not your login account, it will not log you out, I don't fully understand the issue though, I am just adding to the information.
activities.markdown_message: I have added a new video showing the error, even when I have revoked tweetdeck from the twitter account, and then logged out of tweetdeck and logged back in again tweetdeck is still not revoked. I have had my friend try to revoke his account also, and it did not revoke it either. He was using a different computer, different account too. I think I have found the problem, if it is not your login account, it will not log you out, I don't fully understand the issue though, I am just adding to the information.

We're reopened this report to take another look as the issue. We'll be sure you update you once we have more information. 

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message: Any update to this?
activities.markdown_message: Any update to this?

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. 

This is expected behavior. Please see the section on "What will happen to my team members if I revoke TweetDeck access to my Twitter account?" on the [Using the Teams feature on TweetDeck
](https://support.twitter.com/articles/20171753?lang=en) support page.

Thanks for thinking of Twitter Security!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

This is expected behavior. Please see the section on "What will happen to my team members if I revoke TweetDeck access to my Twitter account?" on the Using the Teams feature on TweetDeck
 support page.

Thanks for thinking of Twitter Security!

activities.message: So what if my account was compromised, then added to the attacker's deck and then I got my account back? The attacker can still tweet on my account, reply, retweet and like tweets on behalf of my account. And even though I, the victim have revoked tweetdeck from access from my account the attacker can still use my account. Although this relies on someones account being compromised I still believe this is an issue.
activities.markdown_message: So what if my account was compromised, then added to the attacker's deck and then I got my account back? The attacker can still tweet on my account, reply, retweet and like tweets on behalf of my account. And even though I, the victim have revoked tweetdeck from access from my account the attacker can still use my account. Although this relies on someones account being compromised I still believe this is an issue.

activities.message:
Thanks for the additional information. It appears that the TweetDeck Teams feature is not mentioned on [My account has been compromised](https://support.twitter.com/articles/31796) support page. I'll reopen this issue to continue the investigation.

Thanks for thinking of Twitter Security!
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Apologies for the delay. We consider this issue to be fixed now. The documentation has been updated to provide additional information on how to revoke access to TweetDeck.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
